page.title: 07Stodmarsh Nature Reserve
page.content: How the Reserve was Founded. {____________________________ During the{20th century}lakes formed on the marsh due to mine subsidence. When the mine closed down there was further subsidence and more of the marsh became flooded. The reeds from the river started to spread very rapidly. Then birds started to nest there. The{Nature Conservancy Council realised how important this reed bed was, close to the continent and the sea, so made it into a{reserve. The{nature reserve}is about four hundred acres (one hundred and sixty two hectares), the largest reed bed in Kent and one of the few left in the country. The lakes are about one metre deep but there are many deep pits. This marsh was once completely covered by the sea, separating the{ {Isle of Thanet}from the mainland.
